column2: This is not the time at which I am to enter on the state of my mind beneath its load of sorrow.

column2: I came to think that the Future was walled up before me, that the energy and action of my life were at an end, that I never could find any refuge but in the grave.
column3: I came to think that the Future was walled up before me, that the energy and action of my life were at an end, that I never could find any refuge but in the grave.

column2: I came to think so, I say, but not in the first shock of my grief.

column2: It slowly grew to that. If the events I go on to relate, had not thickened around me, in the beginning to confuse, and in the end to augment, my affliction, it is possible (though I think not probable), that I might have fallen at once into this condition.

column2: As it was, an interval occurred before I fully knew my own distress; an interval, in which I even supposed that its sharpest pangs were past; and when my mind could soothe itself by resting on all that was most innocent and beautiful, in the tender story that was closed for ever.

column2: When it was first proposed that I should go abroad, or how it came to be agreed among us that I was to seek the restoration of my peace in change and travel, I do not, even now, distinctly know.
column3: When it was first proposed that I should go abroad, or how it came to be agreed among us that I was to seek the restoration of my peace in change and travel, I do not, even now, distinctly know.

column2: The spirit of Agnes so pervaded all we thought, and said, and did, in that time of sorrow, that I assume I may refer the project to her influence.

column2: But her influence was so quiet that I know no more.

column2: And now, indeed, I began to think that in my old association of her with the stained-glass window in the church, a prophetic foreshadowing of what she would be to me, in the calamity that was to happen in the fullness of time, had found a way into my mind.

column2: At the request of Traddles, most affectionate and devoted of friends in my trouble, we returned to Canterbury: I mean my aunt, Agnes, and I. We proceeded by appointment straight to Mr. Micawber's house; where, and at Mr. Wickfield's, my friend had been labouring ever since our explosive meeting.

column2: 'My dear madam,' returned Mr. Micawber, 'perhaps I cannot better express the conclusion at which Mrs. Micawber, your humble servant, and I may add our children, have jointly and severally arrived, than by borrowing the language of an illustrious poet, to reply that our Boat is on the shore, and our Bark is on the sea.'

column2: 'With respect to the pecuniary assistance enabling us to launch our frail canoe on the ocean of enterprise, I have reconsidered that important business-point; and would beg to propose my notes of hand--drawn, it is needless to stipulate, on stamps of the amounts respectively required by the various Acts of Parliament applying to such securities--at eighteen, twenty-four, and thirty months. The proposition I originally submitted, was twelve, eighteen, and twenty-four; but I am apprehensive that such an arrangement might not allow sufficient time for the requisite amount of--Something--to turn up.

column2: Turning over, as we are about to turn over, an entirely new leaf; and falling back, as we are now in the act of falling back, for a Spring of no common magnitude; it is important to my sense of self-respect, besides being an example to my son, that these arrangements should be concluded as between man and man.'

column2: My younger children are instructed to observe, as closely as circumstances will permit, the habits of the pigs and poultry maintained in the poorer parts of this city: a pursuit from which they have, on two occasions, been brought home, within an inch of being run over.

column2: I have myself directed some attention, during the past week, to the art of baking; and my son Wilkins has issued forth with a walking-stick and driven cattle, when permitted, by the rugged hirelings who had them in charge, to render any voluntary service in that direction--which I regret to say, for the credit of our nature, was not often; he being generally warned, with imprecations, to desist.'

column2: When I lived at home with my papa and mama, my papa was accustomed to ask, when any point was under discussion in our limited circle, "In what light does my Emma view the subject?" column2: I cannot help thinking,' said Mrs. Micawber, with an air of deep sagacity, 'that there are members of my family who have been apprehensive that Mr. Micawber would solicit them for their names.---I do not mean to be conferred in Baptism upon our children, but to be inscribed on Bills of Exchange, and negotiated in the Money Market.'

column2: Micawber being now on the eve of casting off the pecuniary shackles that have so long enthralled him,' said Mrs. Micawber, 'and of commencing a new career in a country where there is sufficient range for his abilities,--which, in my opinion, is exceedingly important; Mr. Micawber's abilities peculiarly requiring space,--it seems to me that my family should signalize the occasion by coming forward.

column2: I trust,' said Mr. Micawber, solemnly, 'that my son Wilkins will ever bear in mind, that he had infinitely better put his fist in the fire, than use it to handle the serpents that have poisoned the life-blood of his unhappy parent!' Deeply affected, and changed in a moment to the image of despair, Mr. Micawber regarded the serpents with a look of gloomy abhorrence (in which his late admiration of them was not quite subdued), folded them up and put them in his pocket.
column3: I trust,' said mr Micawber, solemnly, 'that my son Wilkins will ever bear in mind, that he had infinitely better put his fist in the fire, than use it to handle the serpents that have poisoned the life blood of his unhappy parent!' Deeply affected, and changed in a moment to the image of despair, mr Micawber regarded the serpents with a look of gloomy abhorrence (in which his late admiration of them was not quite subdued), folded them up and put them in his pocket.

column2: This closed the proceedings of the evening.
column3: This closed the proceedings of the evening.

column2: We were weary with sorrow and fatigue, and my aunt and I were to return to London on the morrow. It was arranged that the Micawbers should follow us, after effecting a sale of their goods to a broker; that Mr. Wickfield's affairs should be brought to a settlement, with all convenient speed, under the direction of Traddles; and that Agnes should also come to London, pending those arrangements.
column3: We were weary with sorrow and fatigue, and my aunt and I were to return to London on the morrow. It was arranged that the Micawbers should follow us, after effecting a sale of their goods to a broker; that mr Wickfield's affairs should be brought to a settlement, with all convenient speed, under the direction of Traddles; and that Agnes should also come to London, pending those arrangements.

column2: We passed the night at the old house, which, freed from the presence of the Heeps, seemed purged of a disease; and I lay in my old room, like a shipwrecked wanderer come home.
column3: We passed the night at the old house, which, freed from the presence of the Heeps, seemed purged of a disease; and I lay in my old room, like a shipwrecked wanderer come home.

column2: We went back next day to my aunt's house--not to mine--and when she and I sat alone, as of old, before going to bed, she said:
column3: We went back next day to my aunt's house-not to mine-and when she and I sat alone, as of old, before going to bed, she said:

column2: 'Trot, do you really wish to know what I have had upon my mind lately?'
column3: 'Trot, do you really wish to know what I have had upon my mind lately?'

column2: 'Indeed I do, aunt.
column3: 'Indeed I do, aunt.

column2: If there ever was a time when I felt unwilling that you should have a sorrow or anxiety which I could not share, it is now.'
column3: If there ever was a time when I felt unwilling that you should have a sorrow or anxiety which I could not share, it is now.'

column2: 'You have had sorrow enough, child,' said my aunt, affectionately, 'without the addition of my little miseries.
column3: 'You have had sorrow enough, child,' said my aunt, affectionately, 'without the addition of my little miseries.

column2: I could have no other motive, Trot, in keeping anything from you.'
column3: I could have no other motive, Trot, in keeping anything from you.'

column2: 'I know that well,' said I. 'But tell me now.'
column3: 'I know that well,' said i 'But tell me now.'

column2: 'Would you ride with me a little way tomorrow morning?' asked my aunt.
column3: 'Would you ride with me a little way tomorrow morning?' asked my aunt.

column2: 'Of course.'
column3: 'Of course.'

column2: 'At nine,' said she.
column3: 'At nine,' said she.

column2: 'I'll tell you then, my dear.'
column3: 'I'll tell you then, my dear.'

column2: At nine, accordingly, we went out in a little chariot, and drove to London.
column3: At nine, accordingly, we went out in a little chariot, and drove to London.

column2: We drove a long way through the streets, until we came to one of the large hospitals.
column3: We drove a long way through the streets, until we came to one of the large hospitals.

column2: Standing hard by the building was a plain hearse. The driver recognized my aunt, and, in obedience to a motion of her hand at the window, drove slowly off; we following.
column3: Standing hard by the building was a plain hearse. The driver recognized my aunt, and, in obedience to a motion of her hand at the window, drove slowly off; we following.

column2: 'You understand it now, Trot,' said my aunt.
column3: 'You understand it now, Trot,' said my aunt.

column2: 'He is gone!'
column3: 'He is gone!'

column2: 'Did he die in the hospital?'
column3: 'Did he die in the hospital?'

column2: 'Yes.'
column3: 'Yes.'

column2: She sat immovable beside me; but, again I saw the stray tears on her face.
column3: She sat immovable beside me; but, again I saw the stray tears on her face.

column2: 'He was there once before,' said my aunt presently.
column3: 'He was there once before,' said my aunt presently.

column2: 'He was ailing a long time--a shattered, broken man, these many years.
column3: 'He was ailing a long time-a shattered, broken man, these many years.

column2: When he knew his state in this last illness, he asked them to send for me.
column3: When he knew his state in this last illness, he asked them to send for me.

column2: He was sorry then.
column3: He was sorry then.

column2: Very sorry.'
column3: Very sorry.'

column2: 'You went, I know, aunt.'
column3: 'You went, I know, aunt.'

column2: 'I went.
column3: 'I went.

column2: I was with him a good deal afterwards.'
column3: I was with him a good deal afterwards.'

column2: 'He died the night before we went to Canterbury?' said I. My aunt nodded.
column3: 'He died the night before we went to Canterbury?' said i My aunt nodded.

column2: 'No one can harm him now,' she said.
column3: 'No one can harm him now,' she said.

column2: 'It was a vain threat.'
column3: 'It was a vain threat.'

column2: We drove away, out of town, to the churchyard at Hornsey. 'Better here than in the streets,' said my aunt.
column3: We drove away, out of town, to the churchyard at Hornsey. 'Better here than in the streets,' said my aunt.

column2: 'He was born here.'
column3: 'He was born here.'

column2: We alighted; and followed the plain coffin to a corner I remember well, where the service was read consigning it to the dust.
column3: We alighted; and followed the plain coffin to a corner I remember well, where the service was read consigning it to the dust.

column2: 'Six-and-thirty years ago, this day, my dear,' said my aunt, as we walked back to the chariot, 'I was married.
column3: 'Six and thirty years ago, this day, my dear,' said my aunt, as we walked back to the chariot, 'I was married.

column2: God forgive us all!' We took our seats in silence; and so she sat beside me for a long time, holding my hand.
column3: God forgive us all!' We took our seats in silence; and so she sat beside me for a long time, holding my hand.

column2: At length she suddenly burst into tears, and said:
column3: At length she suddenly burst into tears, and said:

column2: 'He was a fine-looking man when I married him, Trot--and he was sadly changed!'
column3: 'He was a fine looking man when I married him, Trot-and he was sadly changed!'

column2: It did not last long.
column3: It did not last long.

column2: After the relief of tears, she soon became composed, and even cheerful.
column3: After the relief of tears, she soon became composed, and even cheerful.

column2: Her nerves were a little shaken, she said, or she would not have given way to it.
column3: Her nerves were a little shaken, she said, or she would not have given way to it.

column2: God forgive us all!
column3: God forgive us all!

column2: So we rode back to her little cottage at Highgate, where we found the following short note, which had arrived by that morning's post from Mr. Micawber:
column3: So we rode back to her little cottage at Highgate, where we found the following short note, which had arrived by that morning's post from mr Micawber:

column2: 'Canterbury,
column3: 'Canterbury,

column2: 'Friday.
column3: 'Friday.

column2: 'My dear Madam, and Copperfield,
column3: 'My dear Madam, and Copperfield,

column2: 'The fair land of promise lately looming on the horizon is again enveloped in impenetrable mists, and for ever withdrawn from the eyes of a drifting wretch whose Doom is sealed!
column3: 'The fair land of promise lately looming on the horizon is again enveloped in impenetrable mists, and for ever withdrawn from the eyes of a drifting wretch whose Doom is sealed!

column2: 'Another writ has been issued (in His Majesty's High Court of King's Bench at Westminster), in another cause of HEEP V. MICAWBER, and the defendant in that cause is the prey of the sheriff having legal jurisdiction in this bailiwick.
column3: 'Another writ has been issued (in His Majesty's High Court of King's Bench at Westminster), in another cause of HEEP v MICAWBER, and the defendant in that cause is the prey of the sheriff having legal jurisdiction in this bailiwick.

column2: 'Now's the day, and now's the hour, See the front of battle lower, See approach proud EDWARD'S power-- Chains and slavery!
column3: 'Now's the day, and now's the hour, See the front of battle lower, See approach proud EDWARD'S power- Chains and slavery!

column2: 'Consigned to which, and to a speedy end (for mental torture is not supportable beyond a certain point, and that point I feel I have attained), my course is run.
column3: 'Consigned to which, and to a speedy end (for mental torture is not supportable beyond a certain point, and that point I feel I have attained), my course is run.

column2: Bless you, bless you!
column3: Bless you, bless you!

column2: Some future traveller, visiting, from motives of curiosity, not unmingled, let us hope, with sympathy, the place of confinement allotted to debtors in this city, may, and I trust will, Ponder, as he traces on its wall, inscribed with a rusty nail,

column2: 'The obscure initials,
column3: 'The obscure initials,

column2: M.
column3: M.

column2: 'P.S.
column3: 'p s

column2: I re-open this to say that our common friend, Mr. Thomas Traddles (who has not yet left us, and is looking extremely well), has paid the debt and costs, in the noble name of Miss Trotwood; and that myself and family are at the height of earthly bliss.'
column3: I re-open this to say that our common friend, mr Thomas Traddles (who has not yet left us, and is looking extremely well), has paid the debt and costs, in the noble name of Miss Trotwood; and that myself and family are at the height of earthly bliss.'
